review:
A nice balance between fighting and trap placement places this game above many other tower defence games for me. Upgrades feel meaningful. You're rewarded for doing well. The game feels fun even when it's easy but the challenge the later levels [spoiler](at and past the bridge level)[/spoiler] were the high point for me. 

If you play this game I don't recommend doing any research online, I think a lot of fun comes from trying to figure out what does and doesn't work yourself.

Game completion time: [spoiler](War mage / Normal) Six hours[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198171211154', 'num_games_owned': 1323, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1708358668}
review:
Who knew that slaying orcs could be this fun? For some reason I played the second one first a long time ago, and I rememeber getting stuck at many levels, as they felt too co-op oriented in their design. As this one is single-player only the issue is pretty much non-existent. I also remember a lot of overly tanky enemies, and some of these are present in this entry as well. The only thing that differentiates them from regular "bigger" enemies is the big-ass health bar which can take up to a minute of constant shooting to disappear. It's really annoying and it cocklobcks you from actually managing the enemy horde (so pretty much the fun part of the game) as you have to focus on this one singular guy. It's especially bad when you run out of mana and have to hit him with the basic crossbow, which is a rather shitty deafult weapon. I wish there were more options in that aspect, as every other weapon (aside from the sword, but that one is even worse) uses mana. If it comes to the traps though, there is a pretty big variety of them, and I think everyone can find something they'll like. Not sure if I like the approach of giving the player 1 new thing every level instead of having like a shop where they would unlock whatever they wanted, but as it was the first game in the franchise I'll let it slide.

What else is there to say? It's pretty much a classic at this point, so if you don't have it - buy it. Despite it's shortcomings it probably has one of the best price to fun ratios out there, especiaclly if you consider the on-sale price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198933377955', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1707248511}
review: I liked that you can hop in and play one mission in 20ish minutes and not feel obligated to keep pushing; a good "I have a half an hour to kill" kind of game. While there is a lot of variety in both the level design and the weapons/spells you get, I found myself gravitating toward guardians and the extra money tech tree in almost all cases. That said, I see no reason that other strategies might not be as or more effective and offer a variety of play styles once you understand how certain traps might work well together; some of the combinations are obvious, but I bet there are some I never even noticed. Nightmare mode offers replayability by simply reusing the same 30-odd missions on a higher difficulty. The story is almost non-existent, but what is there is humorous enough to at least make you crack a smile in most of the level intros. (7.5/10)

review: A tower defence game that feels like no other tower defence I've ever tried. The levels are varied and challenging, the traps and spell combinations are very satisfying to use, the story (yes, there is a story!) is interesting, and the game is surprisingly humorous too. Orcs Must Die is very addicting, and it has become a comfort game for me. I find myself coming back to it at least once a year to scratch an itch. Because those orcs gotta die.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116975928', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1826, 'last_played': 1704237207}
review:
Killing orcs is fun, and there are so many ways to kill orcs.

There are plenty of levels, traps, and weapons. There is no one correct way to play, play however you like.

There are 3 difficulties which range from easy to challenging.  Nightmare difficulty has you facing greater varieties of enemies each level while also speeding up the pace of the game.  I thoroughly enjoyed the challenge.

The story and the character dialogue are also great. 

Give this game a try if you are thinking about it.

Tower Defense ist nicht gerade das Genre, wo ich mich total wohlf√ºhle. Aber Orcs Must Die! liefert jede Menge Spa√ü. Die Grafik ist comichaft √ºberzeichnet und sch√∂n animiert. Der Sound passt und der Protagonist kommentiert das Geschehen recht launig (in Deutsch), dazu kommt noch eine fetzige Musikuntermalung. Zu Beginn einer Runde w√§hlt man aus dem immer weiter wachsenden Fundus an Fallen und Waffen die Mittel der Wahl aus. Zu den anf√§nglichen f√ºnf Slots kommen im Verlauf weitere hinzu und man kann somit variantenreicher vorgehen. Kein Spiel um es den ganzen Sonntag zu spielen, aber ein ausgesprochen launiger Zeitvertreib f√ºr den Feierabend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027248391', 'num_games_owned': 1281, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 1016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1016, 'last_played': 1703626582}
review: The game is exactly how the title suggests. Campy fun orc\ogres\kobold\etc. annihilation simulator that certainly does not take itself seriously. It is third person base defence with the help of trusty traps and some very magical gear, but mostly traps against waves of enemies. Plot is sufficiently explained in three cutscenes - developers really managed to tell a bit in that short time about world, situation, who you are and who are your enemies. Music is always dynamic during fight and fit very well with what's going on. Cartoonish style lets it stand the flow of time, so it does not feel outdated or ugly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017912302', 'num_games_owned': 465, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 1875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1662, 'last_played': 1704841404}
review: Orcs Must Die is a staple of the tower defense genre. Instead of just placing defenses and watching enemies get taken out, you can run around and clean up some orcs yourself. Fun levels, fun traps, multiple hours spent trying to 100% everything... The game succeeds at pretty much everything it sets out to do, so if you like what you see on the cover, you won't be disappointed.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197972394559', 'num_games_owned': 1972, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 1382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1382, 'last_played': 1701009334}
review: A fun 3rd person shooter tower defence hybrid with a nice amount of freedom to create fun strategies. It runs well and looks clean but one thing to be aware of is gameplay requires a lot of clicking so your finger may get pretty tired after a while. Story wasn't anything special but was cute and got the job done. There were 2 stale memes I heard from the orcs and protagonist that made me roll my eyes but nothing too offensive, Overall a fun little game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198180446149', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 612, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 612, 'last_played': 1701188130}
review:
Alla prima partita senza accorgermene sono volate 4 ore, mi sono divertito un sacco. 

Non sono per niente un amante del genere ma secondo me questo Tower Defense √® adatto a tutti. Non fatevi ingannare dai video, da giocare ribadisco √® stradivertente. Dategli una possibilit√†.

Per essere un titolo del 2011 graficamente non √® niente male.

I colpi alla testa effettuati con la balestra suscitano soddisfazione.

Sterminare orde su orde di orchi inferociti suscita il triplo della soddisfazione.

Comodo da giocare anche con il controller.  

Forse alla lunga diventa un po' ripetitivo ma mai noioso!

author: {'steamid': '76561198169055269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 221, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1590034723}
review:
Well more or less the right direction of "modernization" of tower defense.  Single player, and "done" with.  So worth the pick up for the price.  Unless you are a purest, or don't understand what I just pointed out.  Or you want the latest and greatest.  

Over all, nice simple game to play by yourself.  With puzzle game-play that makes you plan and think your way to finish the game.  But with enough action to make you feel like the game changer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023374808', 'num_games_owned': 791, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1148, 'last_played': 1638993407}
review:
This is one of the best action tower defense games ever conceived. Visually appealing, solid voice work, an excellent bit of humor and a lot of area to experiment with as well as a good assortment of traps to explore.  A solid progression system for it's time lend to your ability to invest a bit of time into playing as well.

If you're into tower defense but wanted it layered with action gameplay elements instead of just placing towers this is something i would urge you to try.

review: Orcs Must Die! is an absolute blast! The seamless blend of tower defense and third-person action creates an addictive and engaging gameplay experience. The variety of traps and weapons to fend off the orc hordes keeps each level exciting. The graphics and humor add a delightful touch to the overall atmosphere. It's a well-designed, challenging game that keeps you hooked from start to finish. Highly recommended for anyone who loves strategic yet action-packed gaming!

review:
I'm reviewing this very late. Yeah. 

A couple years ago, at least, this was a very fun game! In fact, I don't recommend this game - rather, you should skip to OMD!2, which is just this game but better. 

Despite this, even now, this game is very fun to play through, as I just came back to get the last few achievements I missed over the years. Perhaps buy it for completion's sake, if anything.

[h1] ùïãùï†ùï®ùïñùï£ ùîªùïñùïóùïñùïüùï§ùïñ ùïûùïñùïñùï•ùï§ ‚Ñçùïíùïîùïú ùïü' ùïäùïùùïíùï§ùïô, ùïûùïñùïñùï•ùï§ ùïûùï†ùï§ùï• ùï§ùï•ùï¶ùï°ùïöùïï ùï°ùï£ùï†ùï•ùïíùïòùï†ùïüùïöùï§ùï• ùïñùïßùïñùï£! [/h1]

"Orcs Must Die!" as its name conveys, is a tower defense game that also mixes in a lot of Orc hack n' slashing action.

You are a nameless apprentice, who, after his master dies, becomes the next in line to protect the rifts from the orcs. This "hero" can use traps of all sorts to halt the horde's march, the only problem is that the dude is coocoo. Yup, you are the most stupid protagonist in gaming for this one... So bad actually that your master has given up on teaching you, long ago. For all its flair, the game is actually super cringe, but you'll come to like it... There are like three scenes overall that are quite funny and cringe at the same time, but the magic is when you're playing.

You start off the game by having coins that you can use to set up the arena with traps. Traps range from ballistas all the way to melee knights; the murdering can get quite diverse, and the more stylish you are with your Orcslashing, the higher your combo count is. One of my favourites is the grinder, you couple it with the springtrap and then you watch the Orcs get sprung into the grinder, old gore movies style lol. 

Your hero can also use magic bands, as well as shoot out crossbows and use a sword! I advise against the sword, as you'd want to stay as back from the orcs as possible, especially in Nightmare difficulty.

All in all, I love this game to bits. It's a [b]9.2/10[/b] that I thought lacked Co-Op! Hopefully the next entries are better in that aspect. There is nothing more satisfying than the dance at the end of each level, after you've perfected your Orc-slaying exercise lol.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002506911', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 412, 'playtime_forever': 2655, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2655, 'last_played': 1698529037}
review:
You are a war mage and need to protect the rift from being taken over by the orcs and their many companion monsters.  This is a third person tower defense game where you must set traps, but you as the main protagonist can also fight with sword, bow, or magic to also kill the orcs and the waves of hordes in each level.

There are almost 30 levels to play through and each with their own difficulties.  The curve of difficulty increases as progress through the game.  Multiple doors that the orcs can come from and multiple rifts that you need protect.  Orcs soon lead to ogres, which leads to fire demons, which eventually leads to flying creatures as well.  All of these need to be eradicated before reaching the rift portals or else, if the rifts drop down to zero, you die and must start over.

The traps you have access to continues to grow as you progress through the levels.  You start with simple wall arrows and traps that slow down the orcs and creatures, but eventually you get a swinging mace, hot embers, and other wall mounted traps to help kill the orcs.  How and where you place them are important, but if you want 5 skulls in each level, you will definitely need to learn how to use your magical skills as well as you weapons.

In addition to being able to freeze and light enemies on fire, you can push them with wind or strike them with lightning.  You are limited in mana, so you must wait to replenish your mana prior to firing off more magic spells.  Eventually, you can access a mage RPG like skill tree where you can enhance your traps, your spells, and more during each level, costing you money.  You collect money with every kill, especially if you combo your kills, and sometimes monsters, especially ogres and large creatures will drop coins for you to collect.

Money is limited, health is limited, and mana is limited, which adds to the entire difficulty of the game especially when it is being played on nightmare difficulty.  The achievements for this game are easy to unlock, except for a few which will just require you to play a certain way or obtain 5 skulls on all levels in normal difficulty or beat the game on nightmare which will require some thoughtful placement of traps and timing of when use mana.

Overall, the game is fun, really fun.  The character is a character.  He is not expected to win, but somehow keeps defying logic as to why he's beating the levels.  He acts out and dances when you beat a level and gives a high brow quiver when you get 5 skulls.  I would highly suggest getting this game as it hits everything that you need in a good game.  Great atmosphere, perfect graphics for this type of genre, good music and sound, and enough difficulty to keep you coming back rather than rage quitting.

Diese 5 Level sind in der Levelauswahhl unter der auszuw√§hlenden Kampagne spielbar.

Dieses Spiel hat nur 2 Nachteile: Es k√∂nnten gerne noch mehr Level und Fallen sein und es gibt keinen Multiplayer. 
Der Multiplayer kommt erst im Nachfolger.

review:
[h1] Wurstgulasch, D√∂ner auf dem Teller, Spr√ºhdurchfall nach Wodka-Kirsch [/h1]

Ja - jetzt hast Du eine ungef√§hre Vorstellung davon, wie die Flure hier hier aussehen, die Du mit Orks tapezierst.

LEIDER bleiben die dekorativ verteilten Gr√ºnh√§uter nicht dauerhaft Zierde der G√§nge und R√§ume ;-)

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=685677218

Und bevor manche Grumpy Old Men jetzt wieder monieren: "Das ist keine Rezension!", kommen wir doch gleich mal zum Spielprinzip.

[h1]Du bist ein Zaubererlehrling - bewaffnet mit Armbrust und Schwert - 
UND EINEM BUCH VOLL FIESER FALLEN![/h1]

In Echtzeit steuerst Du Deinen Lehrling durch die G√§nge und Flure einer Zitadelle mit einem Dungeonherz (wie bei Dungeonkeeper!)

Aus ein bis mehreren T√ºren brechen Orkhorden in Wellen herein und versuchen das Dungeonherz zu erreichen.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=623630347

Du! Musst! Das! Verhindern!

Die Grafik ist dabei extrem niedlich und erinnert stark an Molyneux¬¥s Fable.

Auch die Ohren werden verw√∂hnt. Coole orchestrale Musik und ungemein witzige Spr√ºche.

[h1]Da kommentieren die Orks und Du schon mal die Situationen:[/h1]

"Warum schiesst Deine Armbrust 1000 Mal in der Sekunde?"
"Aua - meine F√º√üe tun jetzt weh!" (Wenn sie in eine Falle treten)
oder Du so:
"Das wird mir mehr weh tun als Dir - ach Nein, umgekehrt!"
"Boah, ich glaube, jetzt wird sogar mir schlecht"

Und viele Spr√ºche mehr!

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=903683357

Manchmal musste ich echt lachen. Also so in echt laut. LOL.

Jede Falle kostet eine gewisse Menge Geld, dass wiederum verdient wird, wenn Du Orks schlachtest.

Je nach Deiner [strike]Schnetzelarbeit[/strike] Leistung erh√§ltst Du zus√§tzlich [strike]Erfahrungspunkte[/strike]Erfahrungssch√§del (!!), die Du in die Verbesserung Deiner Fallen investierst.

Neben der Kampagne gibt es auch ein Online-Highscoreboard wie bei fr√ºheren Arcadeautomaten.
Geil.

Hier kannst Du sofort sehen, wer von Deinen Steamfreunden hier pro Level der gr√∂√üere [strike]OrkenMeuchler[/strike] Held gewesen ist.

Ich hatte das Game schon mal auf der Xbox360 durchgespielt.

Ein erneutes kurzes Anspielen hier, hat mich gleich wieder mehrere Stunden suchteln lassen.

Fazit:
[h1]Extrem witziges Game, dass sich anf√ºhlt wie eine Towerdefense-Variante im Fable-Universum. Unbedingt holen. Immer wieder mal Gute Laune f√ºr zwischendrin ist garantiert.[/h1]

review:
Simple fun, for the most part, picking the wrong (or not enough) from your spellbook before you place something will make have a tough time in the later levels.

It's a good setup which I wish games like Fortnite Save the World taken more inspiration from.
If you like the idea of the game and want to play it with friends, go for the sequel, as this one lacks multiplayer.

This game is more than worth its price.

review: not the bad game, but its kind of childish... What I mean - there is no stats for traps. You do not know damage, reset times, manna usage, you do not know how much they change with upgrades. I guess it's meant for kids to have fun and not be overwhelmed with logic. I on the other hand find it frustrating. Still had a bit fun, just couldn't test out all the stuff because of lack of information.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970217779', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1423, 'last_played': 1694302530}
review: Excellent game that still holds up in 2023. Fun mix of TD strategy and action. Gradual difficulty curve as new traps are introduced each level. Lots of replayability after beating the main campaign as the higher difficulty levels introduce different (and more) monsters meaning the strategy you used to beat the level the first time may no longer work. Going for "perfect" levels (no monsters entering the rift, no player deaths, and level beaten within a certain time limit) is also a fun challenge.

author: {'steamid': '76561199261855025', 'num_games_owned': 1308, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 2048, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2048, 'last_played': 1694187819}
review:
Orcs Must Die is an amazingly fun game that definitely causes hours to pass without you noticing. This title definitely falls into the tower defense genre of games, but the speedy controls and solid third-person shooting mechanic make it feel more like an action game throughout. The mixture of these mechanics should really please fans of both, and the casual difficulty makes experimenting with different strategies a lot of fun without consequence. If you even remotely enjoy these types of games I strongly recommend giving this one a go.

PROS:
‚úì Great combat mechanics
‚úì Gameplay is relatively easy to learn
‚úì Lengthy, challenging campaign
‚úì Amount of violence Is great
‚úì Cartoony and bright graphics
‚úì Solid music
‚úì Creating plans and routing the orcs is very rewarding
‚úì Fast paced third-person action with tower defense mechanics

CONS:
- Difficulty curve can sometimes ramp up too quickly
- Certain traps seem so limited in function
- Near-total lack of character and world-building

author: {'steamid': '76561197990036156', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 501, 'playtime_forever': 1884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1884, 'last_played': 1694123498}
review: I can't believe that my negative experience with defense grid awakening made me averse to tower defense games like this for such a long time. Thankfully it is not too late and the game still works OK on modern computers. Despite what the third person view might make you feel, the game does in fact play great and works well. It's definitely a better tower defense game than kingdom rush.

review: An absolute classic. OMD 2 is better IMO, but it's like comparing Doom 1 to Doom 2, the first one is still an absolute classic and still worth playing.

[b]S Tier:[/b]  X-Morph Defense | Warcraft 3 (Custom Maps) | Orcs Must Die! 2 | Orcs Must Die! 3 |

Great game so far!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062923198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1705178159}
review:
Orcs must die! -Einen besseren Titel k√∂nnte es f√ºr diesen makaberen Fantasyspa√ü nicht geben.

Das Ziel ist so klar wie der Titel und der sarkastische Prolog des Uralten Magiers verdeutlichen- Okrs m√ºssen draufgehen, und zwar so viele, wie es nur eben geht. In jedem Level verteidigt ihr eure Festung vor der blutdurstigen Meute, die sich geradewegs auf euer zu besch√ºtzendes  Portal zubewegt. Die bunte Grafik bietet optisch relativ brutalen Splatter in einer cartoonisierten Grafik. Also hier bitte Achtung- nichts f√ºr die ganz jungen Spieler, da eine Menge Blut und K√∂rpperteile durch die Hallen der Festungen fliegen. Der Sound ist entsprechend passend und wird von einem fetzigen Soundtrack untermalt.

Gl√ºcklicherweise habt ihr neben einer Armbrust die ein oder andere Falle zur Verf√ºgung und bekommt immer mehr dazu- diese gilt es gro√üz√ºgig in den Arealen sinnvoll zu verteilen, ebenso wie es euer im Spiel verdientes Budget hergibt. 

Ein motivierendes Punkte- und Upgradesystem steigern den Wiederspielwert. Der "d√ºmmliche" Zauberlehrling, in dessen Rolle man als Spieler schl√ºpft, brabbelt unentwegt drauf los und kommentiert seine kreativen Fallent√∂tungen mit h√∂rbarer Freude- klingt makaber und das ist es auch, aber es passt von Minute eins zum Setting und Grafikspiel des Spiels. Die deutsche Sprachausgabe ist gelungen- Auch die Orks dr√ºcken immer wieder Spr√ºche wie "H√§tte ich in der Schule doch nur besser aufgepasst " etc, w√§hrend sie raunenderweise in die zerstampfenden, aufspie√üenden, verbrennenden, explodierenden, zerschneidenden Fallen rennen.

Verschiedene Gegnertypen zwingen den Spieler etwas dazu, immer wieder neue Kombinationen auszuprobieren. 

Fazit- Ein zynischer "Schnetzelspa√ü", humoristisch, mit so etwas wie einer groben Story und eine Menge Wiederspielwert- vor allem gut f√ºr zwischendurch, die Spielzeit ist ansonsten beim erstmaligem Durchgang √ºberschaubar kurz.

review: Probably the best "action" tower defence I've played. Some stages are difficult but i pretty much loved playing it overall. The only slight i have against this game is the music, it's good but its insanely repetitive and feels like the entire game is just the same track (it actually might be i have no clue i didn't notice any differentiation in the BGM). 8/10 i'd say a must try if you like tower defence and especially dungeon defenders fans.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014492379', 'num_games_owned': 851, 'num_reviews': 500, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1685508138}
review:
The more sources of damage (different traps, different lingering effects, different attacks from you or from guardians) affect an orc as it dies, the more money you get for killing it. Seems a bit obvious, but a lot experienced players still try to space out their traps rather than create condensed areas of diverse death.

On that note, you can add effects even in places you don't expect. For example, orcs that get flung into the abyss by a spring trap will still be comboed by any attack from you or various guardians that lands before they die. So shoot some skeets if you have the time.

Use barricades to create chokepoints, and then heavily trap those chokepoints. Wallblades are awesome early on: If you can make the enemies walk past three or four wallblades with tar traps on the floor, you'll already get rid of most enemies except for goblins and boss enemies. Put brimstone before, in and after the main chokepoint to mop up those goblins. As soon as you get the clockword mace, use it whenever you can. Grinders are pretty good too.

The biggest threats to your barricades are ogres and sappers. With the former, take care not to come within striking distance while they're next to a barricade, or they'll hit it when they attack you. Sappers are tough to deal with, since they will often beeline for your barricades. Try to remember the waves in which they show up, and during those waves, stand in front of your barricades. This will usually cause the sappers to charge you instead of those expensive barricades.

Archers and paladins are awesome. Put some archers with the fire arrow upgrade near your chokepoint, and watch your combo multipliers shoot up. On levels where it's difficult to create good chokepoints, a small army of paladins backed up by archers can save the day.

Steel Weaver is the best weaver for most maps, either because of the trap upgrades, or the guardian upgrades, or both.
The storm cloud is awesome, especially when used near your chokepoint.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066991194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1169, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 967, 'last_played': 1684460907}
review:
A game thats first priority is FUN. The whole game is goofy as hell, and I love how it doesn't take itself seriously. Genuinely funny one liners from the main character, the orcs always babbling away that their feet hurt etc. 

The gameplay is fantastic too, with nearly unlimited amounts of creative freedom in how you tackle a level. I've tried several completely different loadouts and placements of traps on most levels and it's a ton of fun figuring out through creative trial and error what works best.

Would highly reccomend to anyone that wants a really fun game that'll put a smile on their face and make them feel like a genius.

review: Orcs Must Die is an action tower defense game , 3 person view with simple mechanics and lots of traps to help you kill as many orcs as possible. The game has a very short story but funny , it may be old but it holds quite well and provide a lot of fun and action. If you like the idea of defending forts against hordes of orcs and other creatures , using an arsenal of traps , gear and spells combined then give Orcs Must Die series a try.

review: Orcs Must Die! is a great tower defense game, with a lot of variety and replay-ability in it. You have a variety of trap types to deal with the same challenges, and can use clever placement of barricades to direct the orcs, ogres, kobolds, and more into a deadly storm of fire, arrows, and swinging contraptions. This TD game, however, also allows you to use magic and attack with a crossbow/sword staff, allowing for additional strategies to be undertaken. The talent tree system was a nice touch, although I only ever explored the steel one.

review:
Orcs Must Die √© um jogo divertido dentro da sua proposta de tower defense.

Ele traz graficos e detalhamento dos modelos, armadilhas, magias bem ok. Nada que fa√ßa encher os olhos, mas que funciona e deixa o jogo agrad√°vel de jogar.
O jogo possue uma variedade at√© grande de inimigos, dentro do mesmo tipo existe uma varia√ß√£o de modelo tamb√©m o que da uma sensa√ß√£o de sempre inimigos novos chegando.

Os dialogos em cada fase s√£o engra√ßadinhos e um toque a mais na jogabilidade.

A gameplay √© razoavelmente simples mas funciona muito bem, colocar as armadilhas e utiizar o personagem principal e controlavel com suas armas e magias para impedir que o orcs passem pelos portais.
S√£o muitos niveis diferentes com propostas completamente diferentes, sendo que √© necessario utilizar armadilhas diferentes em cada fase se quiser ter sucesso.
O jogo na dificuldade Nightmare faz jus ao nome, pois passar as fases nessa dificuldade √© muito dificil, mas vale muito a pena.
A expans√£o tras algumas fases a mais que tamb√©m s√£o divertidas.

A hist√≥ria √© praticamente inexistente, tendo um conceito de pano de fundo para justificar tudo que acontece no jogo, mas nada que prejudique o todo.

Por fim queria dizer que √© um jogo muito divertido na medida certa, quando eu estava pra ocme√ßar a enjoar ele acabou.
Recomendo muito, especialmente dentro das promo√ß√µes. Sei que ja √© um jogo antigo mas que vale muito a pena ser jogado por quem gosta do genero.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113192300', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 254, 'playtime_forever': 689, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 689, 'last_played': 1474209438}
review:
Here are several reasons to play Orcs Must Die!:

It's the ultimate stress reliever! What's more satisfying than mowing down hordes of orcs with an arsenal of traps and weapons?

The game combines tower defense and action elements, so you'll never get bored.

Orcs. Need we say more? Who doesn't love a good, old-fashioned orc massacre?

The game has a great sense of humor, with hilarious dialogue and quirky characters that will keep you entertained for hours.

It's a great way to test your strategy skills. Can you strategically place your traps and defend your stronghold against the relentless orcs?

There are a ton of different traps and weapons to choose from, so you can mix and match to create the ultimate orc-killing machine.

The game has a cooperative mode, so you can team up with a friend and take on the orcs together.

The graphics are top-notch, with beautiful, detailed environments and satisfying animations.

The game has a lot of replay value, with different difficulty levels and endless mode to keep you coming back for more.

Did we mention the orcs? Seriously, they're the best.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049459983', 'num_games_owned': 421, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2055, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2055, 'last_played': 1561730435}
review:
Orcs Must Die is a game that's all about killing orcs... and having a good laugh while doing it! This game is full of silly humor and over-the-top action that will have you giggling like a madman (or madwoman) in no time.

First of all, the game's protagonist is a classic comic relief character. He's a bumbling wizard with a sarcastic wit, and his quips and jokes are sure to bring a smile to your face. And let's not forget about the orcs themselves - these green-skinned monsters are so absurd and silly that you can't help but laugh at their antics.

The game's traps and weapons are also a source of humor. From exploding barrels to spring-loaded traps, there's no shortage of wacky and hilarious ways to take out the orcs. And with a wide range of upgrades and customization options, you can create the ultimate orc-slaying arsenal that will have your enemies running for the hills (or in this case, the dungeons).

But the real humor in Orcs Must Die comes from the game's over-the-top violence. Whether you're slicing orcs in half with a giant sword or blowing them up with a well-placed bomb, the game is a non-stop barrage of absurdity that will have you in stitches.

In conclusion, if you're looking for a game that's all about killing orcs and having a good laugh, then Orcs Must Die is the game for you. So grab your wizard hat, grab your weapons, and get ready to take on the orc horde in the most hilarious way possible!

review:
Wer Tower Defense mag, MUSS dieses Spiel haben. Es ist so witzig und abwechslungsreich. Grandios!! Ein super dickes Danke an Robot Ent. f√ºr das geniale Spiel. Vielleicht das beste Spiel, das ich je gespielt habe.
Mittlerweile habe ich alle drei Teile und k√§mpfe mich immer noch durch die Orchorden. Selbst Level die man schon geschafft hat, kann man mit anderen Waffen oder Fallen neu spielen. Fun, Fun, Fun.
Als Bonus zum Spiel gibt es hunderte von irrwitzigen Videos auf Youtube, wie man es noch besser oder anders machen kann.

author: {'steamid': '76561198872865296', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 173, 'last_played': 1699238341}
review:
I originally played this game on a thumb drive in a computer lab. Played it a lot, then I played it on some weird streaming service. The point is, I have more hours than it shows.

The game is simple, there's no gear to collect or classes like dungeon defenders. You don't build mazes with blocks like in sanctum. You just have a blockade to adjust their path, and a bunch of traps to kill them. Then  you have a few weapons and some magic to fight as well, each of which compete with the towers for space in each map. You take whatever you think will work best, and that's it. You get skulls depending on how well you did on each level, and for how quickly you completed each level. You use these skulls to upgrade your traps.

On the one hand, the upgrades give you a reason to try getting more skulls and to replay the maps. On the other hand, it means when you first get a trap, it will just be worse until you come back later and try again. That sort of gimps you on your first attempt of each level, unless you just rely on older towers you've already upgraded.  This in a way necessitates playing each level again to get a better score. On the other hand, you get stronger as you go through the game, in a very simple linear way.

You'll also need to do some fighting in order to get a good score, especially to end the early rounds quickly. This can be seen as a good thing by forcing you to be active in defending the dungeon. On the other hand, it forces you to be active, rather than allowing you to rely on traps. To some degree your playstyle will always be balanced. There's also no worrying about repairing traps like in Dungeon Defenders, you just put them down and you're fine.

The game is simple from a mechanical standpoint, but can also get a bit complicated on later levels managing each entry point and going around culling waves yourself or working on your defenses. Overall I'd recommend this if you're into first person tower defense games, and it's a good entry point into that specific sub genre. If you want to play with other people you'll need to try Orcs Must Die 2 though. But this is a good single player game.

You also don't need the dlc, the base weapons are good, but it's nice to have them for the sake of variety, and it's worth getting the dlc if it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119924330', 'num_games_owned': 438, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1672431688}
review:
Ridiculously hard and unfair. Your weapons and fortifications barely do any damage. Enemy archer's arrows can go behind covers, track you etc.

It falls to the hole, that some of the worse td games. It's very strict. Every level has exactly one solution. The game has many weapons and many barricades, but you can't use them to your liking. You can't go and have fun with trying out different variations, solutions, because the game won't let you. A huge letdown.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960938493', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 937, 'last_played': 1674070210}
review:
[b]I played Orcs Must Die in 2022 and had an absolute blast.[/b]

While this game is [b]considerably more basic[/b] than [b]Orcs Must Die 2[/b], I found it to be much more challenging. However, [b]it is only single player[/b].

Your objective is to stop [b]Orc Hordes[/b] that are trying to cross [b]The Rift[/b]. To achieve this, you will need to use [b]your creativity[/b], [b]weapons[/b], and [b]traps[/b] to [b]kill them all[/b].

[b]This game has two DLCs[/b], and while both are cheap, the "[b]Lost Adventures[/b]" one unlocks a ton of content. If you can find them in a bundle for a good price, they are definitely worth it. Otherwise, just go for the "[b]Lost Adventures[/b]."

Also, if you buy this game, [u]it is like getting a DLC for Orcs Must Die 2[/u], because [b]you will unlock ten levels from this game in OMD2[/b]. If you are planning to play [b]OMD2[/b], [u]you absolutely have to get this game[/u]!

If you are looking for a [b]more polished version[/b] of this game, just go for [b]Orcs Must Die 2[/b].

author: {'steamid': '76561198002051803', 'num_games_owned': 201, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 1643, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1595, 'last_played': 1676712991}
review:
This game runs on Linux without any issues.

It's also magnificently fun. It also has some small tower defence elements although it's not really a TD, Sanctum 2 feels more tower-defencey but this is more action-oriented and trap based rather than actual towers - so be very mindful of that going in.

It took me 25 hours to finish the game, including Nightmare difficulty and every achievement. However, I don't have the DLC so you could get another 5-ish levels.

Everything about this game is awesome. The gameplay is awesome, many great and unique levels, the small bits of dialogue is pretty funny but not in-your-face. Plenty of traps and combinations to explore!

Any weaknesses? Well there are a few but they didn't take much away from the game, just possible areas of improvement. Such as making the game longer, maybe a better/actual story (though I don't really expect that in a game like this).

Perhaps some levels on Nightmare become too reliant on certain traps or combinations but most games have a "meta" that develops on the higher-end and you still have a variety of choices rather than 1 answer so it's nothing troubling.

I guess some bugs like a few finicky tile placements, the occasional cross-bow aim/reticle glitch, and oddly my fans run quite fast on this game so I have to take small breaks or reload to clear memory etc. Butt the game never crashed nor did any little bug ruin any of my runs.

I would've also liked some custom or survival modes, perhaps in the other games I might see this.

All in all, I loved this game and kinda sad that I finished it, I will definitely buy the sequal(s) and maybe the cheap level-pack DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561199202501476', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1598, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1598, 'last_played': 1670284929}
review:
[h1] Orcs Must Die! (2011), 85/100 [/h1]

[i] - Dead Orc = Good Orc. [/i]


[b] 10 HIGHLIGHTS [/b]

- Tower defense, strategy, 3rd person action combat, thousands of orcs will die, build traps, choke points, headshots, colorful, comical, cheap.


[b] TO SUM UP... [/b]

- Worth it, plain fun. Fast paced action in short sessions, with fantastic gameplay and enough strategy depth. Easy but funny tower defense game with colorful and comical visuals & sounds.


[i] Played Build ID 16691, December 2022, Windows 10, Lenovo Legion. [/i]

[i] - Stable: not a single bug or crash. [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561197990913342', 'num_games_owned': 879, 'num_reviews': 193, 'playtime_forever': 2409, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2409, 'last_played': 1668706167}
review:
A classic of tower defense and 3rd person action combat, Orcs Must Die 1 is a pristine relic of the 2010s. I am a huge fan of this series, clearing through it on all difficulties back to back and then working to improve my scores for a few dozen hours before going even harder in OMD2. I gobbled up the reasonably priced DLCs, placed a few triple digit entries in a six+ digit playerbase and felt satisfied. Nowadays I have the smooth-brained notion to review every game I own and playing OMD3 got me wondering if nostalgia was affecting my appreciation of the new vs the old.

Ah, to see Max's cocky eyebrow waggle over the shield at the end of a level again, assuring me that I didn't let a single enemy through. OMD1 is still as snappy, addictive and fun as ever.  The enemy and trap/weapon/spell roster are a bit small compared to the glory to come but they are a lovingly refined set of tools. In Orcs Must Die there are a bunch of orcs and they must be murdered. Well, there's the generic good-aligned Order that keeps the world safe from endless tides of orcs and there's a jaunty, enjoyable set of inner monologues with apprentice Max and then outer dialogues with something wicked but OMD isn't a series that gets into deep stories, instead providing some pretty good VA work(thanks Robert McCollum) and force of personality for our cocksure fantasy medieval Bruce Campbell(you know, another one) to frame why all these dang orcs keep invading.

We're here for the gameplay and does OMD deliver. You're given a central point to defend and a steady stream of enemies march towards it along preset paths. Set traps and beat them up to stop them, if they reach the rift too many times you lose. You get a gleefully sadistic set of traps and spells to even the odds of man vs army, traps delivering a preset function and then taking a bit of time to reset in most cases and your own strength of arms and spells being limited by how long you can hold off arthritic symptoms caused by clicking or your mana bar. Identity the paths, set traps at the best points to maximize damage, thin the herd and take down those that get through yourself. If things are going well then enjoy the wonderful combo system, where the more things that have debuffed or damaged an enemy recently before they die multiplies the cash they drop by a generous percentage. The difference between a combo-killing killbox and thinning mooks out one by one can easily be doubling your killbox size!

Lest you get too complacent Orcs Must Die delivers a superb difficulty balance, constantly pushing you to try new things and improve your play. Get too cozy using the same strategy and elemental immune enemies show up to ignore half of your stuff. Large enemies in OMD are huge and heavy, hitting hard, and the fast runners or cheeky fliers have ruined many a perfect run by slipping through. Sappers and Gnolls also try to upset your idle sit and wait approach, OMD being a game that rewards both strong defense and proactive offense. The roster is a bit lighter here compared to later games but like the smaller spellbook it is compact instead of lacking, carrying the game with the level design and solid controls.

What makes OMD so good is the manic feel of the gameplay, the snappy response of your character movement, the ability to sprint to a new panic spot on the map and flip between weapons to mix in what you need on the spot, to even slam down emergency traps with a good intuitive feel. It's something you have to experience for yourself when you're trying to secure a win, push the higher difficulties or get a better score. Just the responsive, reliable feel of the crossbow and the little narrowing of the targeting circle for those steady headshots, it is a real chef's kiss of vidya design. Like Mario 64 this is an impossibly polished set of good controls. The game still looks good today thanks to strong art direction and the soundtrack remains a steady set of medieval bangers.

The DLCs add five levels, two enemies and a few items and spells respectively. Fine additions once the base game hooks you and at $10 to start and a few dollars for the DLC things are quite reasonable. If you've not tried the OMD series and enjoy tower defenses even very generally I think this is an easy recommendation, a game whose lightning in a bottle mix of satisfying gameplay and feedback, creative experimentation in approach and gritty but not overly strict difficulty just hit a perfect mixing point of developer passion and talent. OMD1 is still arguably the best of the series and that's pretty good for the game that started it all.

review:
"Orcs must die!" is a fun tower defense game that gets more rewarding, the more you play. If you ever wished to play dungeon interior designer and find joy in murdering waves of orcs, look no further. 

The one thing missing to make this game an absolute masterpiece is our lord and saviour, Shrek. Even if he is an ogre.

review: Orcs Must Die! est un bon m√©lange de TPS et d√©fense de tour, avec d‚Äôassez beaux graphismes et une bande son correcte. La jouabilit√©, √† la manette, est bonne, avec des contr√¥les simples et intuitifs ; il est √©galement possible de jouer au clavier et √† la souris, avec des contr√¥les qui ne peuvent pas √™tre modifi√©s mais qui sont bien assign√©s. Concernant le sc√©nario, celui-ci est tr√®s basique et anecdotique. Orcs Must Die!, bien qu‚Äôon y fasse toujours la m√™me chose, ne s‚Äôav√®re pas trop r√©p√©titif gr√¢ce √† trois points forts : sa diversit√©, que ce soit d‚Äôennemis, de niveaux, d‚Äôarmes ou de pi√®ges, qui est tr√®s correcte ; son c√¥t√© fun, d√©foulant et bourrin ; la relative rapidit√© pour terminer un niveau, ce qui fait qu‚Äôil est √©galement adapt√© pour de petites sessions de jeu. author: {'steamid': '76561198038484993', 'num_games_owned': 126, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1666147422}
review:
TLDR:  Enjoyable tower defense game that doesn't take itself too seriously.

When the old master war mage suffers an accidental--and embarrassing--death, it's up to his apprentice to turn back the tides and stuff the orcs back in their hole ... only, he has no idea what he's doing.

Orcs Must Die is a tower defense game like many others, of twenty-some levels split into three acts, with some amusing cinematics between them. The levels consist of barred doors with the orcs beating at the other side, and long castle corridors leading to the mysterious rifts. The player has time to lay traps, assign guardians, and so on before launching the assault--and then when the orcs come, blast them down in 3rd-person shooter-style perspective. Head shots do extra damage, as they should.

The concept is simple but the strategy can be surprisingly deep. Some of the castles have multiple approaches to multiple rifts (one wonders who designed these things) and the player may have to deal with simultaneous assaults from different angles. This is where the strategy comes in; there are various traps to inflict damage, slow the enemy, or spring-loaded panels to fling them away. The player will also earn fire, ice, and wind attacks. Some levels feature environmental aids (hot oil cauldrons, chandeliers to be dropped, spiked logs that roll down steps) that can be used one or more times. Archer or sword guardians can be summoned. After the first act, the player will be contacted by the weavers, powerful sorceresses who offer buffs--for a price, of course.

With limited coin (and time between most waves) to place traps, planning and forethought to build a cohesive defense is key. Attempt different set-ups and don't be afraid to blow a round or two to test a strategy.The player won't get the ceiling mace (swings back and forth, crushing everything underneath it) until after the halfway point, but the mace angled along the orc approach (meaning it swings parallel to the hallways, not across) with barricades to channel the orcs under it, and tar traps to slow down attackers and keep them under the mace, are incredibly effective.

Against this will come warrior orcs (bearing shields in later levels, that nullify the first hit), archer orcs, kobald runners (who don't attack but run fast for the rift) and sappers (who detonate barricades), ogres (slow but hard to put down), hobgoblin shamans (they resurrect dead enemies), and gnoll hunters (who ignore the rift but are fast, jump barricades, and track the player and guardians). Later levels introduce flying mobs, which add a new dimension of complexity to the defenses.

All of this will take practice to perfect and no one trap will account for all enemies. The ceiling mace I mentioned, for example, won't swing fast enough to catch every kobold and ogres can survive the hits and keep coming. Again, I recommend you experiment and take chances on different defenses. The nice thing is that the levels are relatively short. I think I did all of them in under 25 minutes, and they only took that long because I spent several minutes planning my defenses. It's n easy game if you just want to play for a few minutes and mow down a horde of bad guys. There are three difficulty levels: Apprentice, War Mage, and Nightmare, with scaling difficulty.

The game loads quick and I didn't encounter any glitches, save a few odd instances enemy corpses getting tossed into the environment, where they got stuck. The graphics are animated and clean, but smooth. Sound is good and provides key notices, such as if orcs break through a certain point, or faint howls when the gnoll hunters enter the map. Also, the player's war mage has some humorous lines at the start of each level. The whole thing, in fact, has a fairly tongue in cheek feel, and I enjoyed the humor.

If the game has a failing, it is that, like most tower defense games, it can get very repetitive. Also, the deeper into the campaign you go, the less margin for error there is and the harder it is to control all the lanes of attack. One viable option is to play all the way through on Apprentice, in order to get all the traps and spells available (once granted, they remain for replays of earlier maps or other difficulties).

Steam achievements are mostly doable by players of any skill and other than those directly tied to difficulty level, they can be done on the easiest settings.

All in all, Orcs Must Die is a fun time-waster, with some good humor and interesting strategic set-ups. Recommended!

Pros
- Good mix of strategy and action
- Smooth graphics, textures, and sounds

Cons
- Can get repetitive, and difficult before having all available traps

Final Score: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198068174012', 'num_games_owned': 690, 'num_reviews': 384, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1665760188}
review:
Orcs Must Die! (2011)

Extremely fun game to play with a simple premise - orcs swarm the portal, you place traps to kill the orcs and that stops them from swarming the portal, permanently. Your Warmage character can use different weapons to help in the slaughter but they tend to drain your mana with each use, so strong and great to have around but best used sparingly. The traps you can use involve stuff like spike traps, grinders that suck orcs in and... well grind them to dust, archers that can shoot flying enemies and orcs, spikes that shoots from the walls, sticky tar that slows orcs. Get sadistic and creative with the traps, you have plenty of options. About halfway through the game you unlock these fine ladies who will help either your traps, your weapons and mage abilities or a good mix of great non trap related defences. I prefer the trap upgrades, it always felt for me it had the most inpact. Each level you complete unlocks skulls based on how well you performed, you use these skulls to permanently upgrade your traps before starting a new mission.

There are a lot of levels to this game, I do not know if the dlc content adds any maps to the game but I have all the content for the game so for me it's just one big game. Lots of maps with different layouts and certain traps works better with certain maps. Its a great game to play, but I found myself finishing a few levels at a time instead of one big push to finish the game. It worked better for me, gave me a refreshed insight to each level. Its a very creative game to play and I highly recommend you give this game a go.

8/10

review: After beating OMD2 three times and being very let down by OMD3, I went back and played the original orc slaying, action tower defense game that started the franchise. The formula still works well and it's a really fun game. That said 2 improves on everything that is good in this game. The rankings very clearly go 2 > 1 > 3. Get your fill on 2 before trying 1 and just go back and play 2 if you're considering playing 3.

author: {'steamid': '76561198357137407', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 1079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1079, 'last_played': 1663512376}
review:
Even a smartphone tower difference game is better than this. poor map designs, useless traps/weapons, and countlessly meaningless battles. I would hardly find what good this game is as a tower difference.

No fun to explore a map. Each map is designed to use traps in specific places, like even if the map is complicatedly huge, the best strategy is always choosing a small space to set accurate traps against enemies.

Most traps are useless or used for a very specific case especially in the hard difficulty. So in the later game, most people use a similar type of traps/weapons unless they follow some own challenging rule.

So since you had limited choices of your traps and areas, the fight is also critically boring. Early waves are fine, you still have to get a point to develop your traps gradually. However after 5 waves, setting your traps are most likely done and still you have over 5 waves to complete a level which means you just attack enemies or watch your traps in the same way over and over in the rest of waves because enemies are also same. This is painfully boring especially in the later game.

$10 is not expensive but also you have a choice to use your $10 in another way. No need to play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042838100', 'num_games_owned': 740, 'num_reviews': 94, 'playtime_forever': 534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 534, 'last_played': 1661924813}
review:
[h1]TL;DR brand new to the series, and it's really good[/h1]
I haven't played the second or third game, and decided to start from the beginning. It's a remarkably solid game with a lot of different ways to play. It strikes the perfect balance between being able to set up a fully-automatic meat grinder and having your plans fail, forcing you into a final stand at the rift without a trap in sight. You might be tempted to skip this and go straight into the newer games, but this game is absolutely worth playing if you're looking to get into the series. I went into it assuming I'd rush through it to quickly get to the sequels, but I was blown away with how fun it was as its own experience.

[h1]The perfect challenge[/h1]
I went through the game in about 8 hours, playing leisurely and sometimes restarting levels to get a better score. I haven't played a game with the PERFECT level of challenge in a while. On the normal difficulty, you need to use a combination of traps and weapons to get high scores on each level. If you have a smooth brain like I do, you'll rely on your weapon almost as much as your traps when the orcs start getting dangerously close to the rift. One round you might not fire a single arrow because your traps are doing all the work, and the next round you could be fighting for your life because the orcs found a flaw in your plan.

[h1]An addictive gameplay loop[/h1]
You lay traps and shoot orcs to prevent them from getting to your rift. The more orcs that survive your setup and make it to the rift, the less [b]skulls[/b] you get. These [b]skulls[/b] are spent on persistent upgrades for your traps which makes it really fun to come up with an efficient solution for each level. After every level you unlock something, which is a new trap or weapon 90% of the time.

[h1]Creative freedom[/h1]
One of the best parts about the game is the amount of traps/weapons/units, and the many viable ways to play. Whether it's building a maze filled with tar that forces the orcs to slowly inch through a hall of saws and spikes, or leading an army of archers and warriors to defend a chokepoint, you really can play however you like and succeed. This is enhanced by the upgrade system because you can choose your favorite traps and make them stronger. Upgraded traps and units are noticeably better, but not enough to leave your other ones useless, so you really can experiment without being punished.

[h1]This game is very well-designed and a must play for tower defense fans[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198087410341', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1657847741}
review:
The graphics look nice, controls straightforward and gameplay decent. Although, playing it alone feels lackluster.

The main problem is balance. Forget about close combat, because enemies deal too much damage up close. You'll find that sticking with the default crossbow and acid bottle is the best choice. You can do pretty creative things with the traps, but they all feel underpowered with how much cannon fodder slips through the cracks.

The most annoying part is the cringeworthy dance your character does at the end of each level.

The game is not my thing, but it's alright.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025317792', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 6079, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6079, 'last_played': 1657350924}
review:
I was going through a tough period in my life in 2021 and didn‚Äôt find pleasure in much of everything, including my enjoyment of video games that I had since I was a kid.  I‚Äôve collected thousands of games and so never know what to play.  For some reason, I tried this‚ÄîI think it‚Äôs because I liked Dungeon Defenders and so this was a single player version of it.  This idea of combining third-person shooting with strategically placing traps (note: I don‚Äôt like pure tower defense games because I don‚Äôt get to do anything) intrigued me.

This game brought back my enjoyment of gaming.  I played the first few levels and was hooked.  What enemies were there in this level?  Which traps would I select?  How would I combine them?  Where would I set up the kill box?  Which wave would I have to get to in order to earn enough points to make a kill box impenetrable?  If it wasn‚Äôt, how would I use my crossbow and spells to either hold them off or catch the stragglers?  I would try something, and it might work okay or I might lose.  The amazing thing: I DIDN‚ÄôT MIND LOSING!  Every loss was another chance to change my strategy and learn something new about optimizing my strategy.  I never used a guide and beat the War Mage difficulty and felt so satisfied upon completion.

A year later, and I feel a little down again.  I remember the rush of playing this game and reinstall it‚Äîsomething I NEVER do because I have so many games that it‚Äôs not worth replaying.  I play it again on the Nightmare difficulty.  I die a lot.  I only occasionally barely get frustrated when I make a dumb mistake; the rest of the time, I enjoy learning what doesn‚Äôt work and why and then change my strategy next time.  After dozens of hours of gameplay, I beat nightmare mode 5-skull for all levels and even score top 1,500 in the world for some of the highest-difficulty levels (something that I usually don‚Äôt care about but am happy that I did it).  I did look up videos to see if I was missing any strategies that I‚Äôd like, and it was amazing to see someone take the level on in a completely different way and still being able to get 5 skulls, making your gameplay approach so diverse vs. one optimal strategy per se.

What an amazing game that I thoroughly enjoyed.  Love the learning process and experiment.  Enjoy the satisfaction of discovering a trap combination that makes your defenses impenetrable.  I only have one beef: the game has one bug where your crossbow shots go flying diagonally upward when your enemy is on a staircase.  It drove me nuts and cost me a few runs on the latter stages when seconds can mean the difference between success and failure.  But otherwise, it‚Äôs an amazing game that I highly recommend.  Just avoid the temptation that I succumbed to where I was up until 4am+ making sure I beat a level before I had to give up for the day and forget the enemy wave patterns I memorized for the level.  But I loved every minute of it, and games like this are what make gaming such a joy in life.  Cherish these games and these moments, as they remind you why it‚Äôs great to be alive.

Oh, one more minor beef: for the weaver upgrades, just tell us which traps the upgrades apply to.  ‚ÄúAll physics traps‚Äù or ‚Äúall piercing and cutting traps‚Äù didn‚Äôt help me‚Äîand the internet was even ambiguous about which ones they applied to.  Just tell me which traps get bonuses!

author: {'steamid': '76561198107212373', 'num_games_owned': 467, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 157, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 157, 'last_played': 1558894561}
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156106597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 957, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1682925382}
review: Orcs Must Die! is a real gem to start off. Its a classic back in the xbox 360 generation and it holds up to this day on PC. Its simplistic and gets challenging along the way. I have to say the DLC could be better as the DLC campaign does not introduce anymore story or lore. The other trap DLC is lackluster and should have contained more items in my opinion. Even though this game is like a decade old or more, its a great start for anyone that is looking into this franchise. I recommend that you purchase the game when it is on sale. I bought the game and DLC back in summer sale of 2022. There are no bugs that I have experienced with this relic. When you download the game, it will ask you to download another piece of old software (DIRECTPLAY) for multiplayer I think but it is not vital. Its meant to be a good single-player strategy tower defense like game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018708499', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 16696, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16680, 'last_played': 1656578014}
review:
I just now realise I've never written a review for this awesome game, so let's fix that.

Orcs Must Die! is a simple game about killing orcs and killing lots of them. The game plays like a third-person shooter with tower defence mechanics that allows you to place different kinds of traps that will assist you in the killing of orcs. Whether you prefer to play more actively and shoot down as many orcs yourself, or invent trap combinations that will do most of the heavy lifting for you is up to you, and there is a good variety of weapons and traps to choose from to experiment with.

Despite being over 10 years old at this point, Orcs Must Die! holds up extremely well, visually, thanks to its cartoony aesthetic. The music, sounds and voice acting is all well done and adds greatly to the overall experience. My only complaints with this game would probably come from some missing settings I would have liked to see, such a windowed fullscreen mode and a separate audio slider for voices amongst some other things. There are also some quality of life features missing that have been implemented in the later entries, but none of these are dealbreakers in any way to me. In my opinion, the first Orcs Must Die! is a timeless classic and I'd still consider it the best game in the series, at least if you care more about the single-player experience. If you're looking to play this with a friend, this is not the game for you. Go get OMD2 or 3 instead, in that case.

Ê≠¶Âô®„Å®ÁΩ†„Çí‰Ωø„Å£„Å¶„É™„Éï„Éà„Å®„ÅÑ„ÅÜÊã†ÁÇπ„Çí„Ç™„Éº„ÇØ„Åü„Å°„Åã„ÇâÂÆà„ÇãTPS & TD „Ç≤„Éº„É†

author: {'steamid': '76561197992880692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 550, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 549, 'last_played': 1655999789}
review:
Orcs Must Die! is an action third person shooter, tower defense hybrid. You use spells, weapons and traps to kill hordes of orcs as they make their way to your rift.

Unfortunately for this game, it has been all but overshadowed by its sequel Orcs Must Die! 2. Seriously, every mistake or misstep they make in this game they fix and do better in the next. There is almost no reason to get this game, just get 2. That said, on its own merits, its still a really fun and frantic game to play.

The core gameplay is you start a map that has one or more paths to one or more rifts. Creatures that range from basic orcs, to fast kobolds, to tanky ogres comes out in waves heading to the rift and you must stop them. While you do build a variety of traps, and can even eventually start determining their path by building barricades, there is more of a focus on twitchy, frantic orc killing with a variety of weapons and spells. Maps getting increasingly difficult, usually with you needing to monitor multiple paths, and there is a little bit of a story told in some cutscenes and dialogue. As you go along you unlock more spells, weapons and traps to use and can upgrade them as well.

This game really has a dynamite premise. It is immense fun to just mow down the hordes, and it is oh, so satisfying to watch a synergy of your devices really work and do their thing. I cannot overstate how good the core of this game is, they really hit on something here.  The game is even pretty funny at times with its doofus main protagonist who just lives for orc killing.

I have a lot of nitpicks though. There is only one real tileset for maps, so aesthetically they all look the same. There is not a huge amount of enemy variety, just enough. The enemy pathing does not function very well. I experienced a lot of buggy enemy animations. There are not many game modes. The weaver upgrade system is weak. The meta progression of skulls can't be refunded to try different things. The only women in the game are the 3 weavers who are overtly sexualized and they somehow messed up something in their recording their voices (there is also technically the bad guy who is also sexualized...). 

And all of these things are either fixed or at least improved in the sequel. Like literally every single negative thing I have to say about this game, every criticism, they address it. 

So this is basically an advertising for Orcs Must Die! 2. Go buy that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966597554', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 98, 'playtime_forever': 1191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1191, 'last_played': 1653266911}
review:
Orcs must die 1 is a fun tower defense/action hybrid.

This game acts as a map pack for the second game, while also having some different game mechanics and some unique maps that weren't ported over to the second. While lacking in some various but small quality of life improvements compared to the second game I'd say the gameplay is roughly the at a similar polish level as the second game.

It's a good time, it feels fun to play and experiment with different trap combinations to make the ultimate self sufficient meatorizor. Would reccomend playing with a controller, as with the PC version the repeating crossbow is not actually a repeating crossbow. For whatever reason this carries forward to the second game so yay RSI.

Certainly worth while grabbing on a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961169351', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1915, 'last_played': 1652548848}
review:
Just finished Nightmare mode, and I gotta say I still love this game, and while I haven't tried OMD3, the sequel to this OMD2 just does not give the same satisfaction as the original. I come back to this game to feel out what a great Tower Defense Game is rly all about: Building a kill box and seeing what could actually possibly survive it, and then making a better kill box to eliminate the remainder.

If i had to guess what gives this one so much more magic compared to the sequel... I just think that the sequels rely too heavily on simply making the levels bigger or longer. Instead of figuring out how to best use the features of the room/building to put traps/towers on to defend, the Sequel has you filling too much of the damage with your own character's attacks. And when you design more of the levels to be longer, the design starts to be more about making more DPS per area as opposed to solving a room's limitations by using different traps. I.e. There's no walls, so you have to rely on ceiling and floor traps, or there's not much flat ground for floor traps, so you have to use ceiling traps. And don't get me wrong, the sequel has a little of that, but every trap feels so much weaker and that you have to add way more traps and add more character damage to compensate. The 1st game has levels designed like puzzles to be solved approximately with traps, with some room for error that you can cover with weapons, and the 2nd game feels like needing to cram as much damage on the field to kill incoming enemies, and if you don't use your weapons and weapon abilities everytime, you will lose.

Orcs Must Die! (the original) makes you feel powerful when you place your traps, and the second game, traps feel so weak.

I sincerely hope that the team behind these games changes their design philosophy. I want to change the room to solve a tower defense puzzle, not figure out how to best use my character's attack abilities to pair with the towers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002716193', 'num_games_owned': 716, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 1877, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1877, 'last_played': 1651424996}
review:
*Warning: spoilers*

So much fun! 

Orcs Must Die! is a fun game full of action, tension, a great soundtrack, and a good sense of humour. On its own it is just a tower defence game with twenty-four levels where you fight off waves of bloodthirsty orcs and ogres. What makes it unique for me at least, is the real time action in which you can place your traps at any time, upgrade your skills, fight off orcs hand to hand and quickly navigating through the map all at once, unlike other tower defence games.

Orcs Must Die! has a little story which is good enough for such a simple game and is filled with lots of jokes and dry humour. It does not take itself too seriously and I like that.

Graphicly this game is not that amazing, but it does not need to. Like I mentioned before, the soundtrack is great. It really helps when playing and does add that glorious feeling to the battles. It is one of the better soundtracks I heard in a while.

The controls and mechanics for placing traps are smooth and work perfectly, this might be expected but there are lots of games where the controls ruin the game for you, luckily this is not the case here.

As much fun as this game was, the only problem I had with it, was that it was too easy. Once you master a specific strategy (like placing tar pits, grinders, and barricades) you can practically beat any level without many problems using this same strategy.

Overall, I would recommend Orcs Must Die! It is certainly worth a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561198174621953', 'num_games_owned': 202, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 588, 'last_played': 1650459926}
review:
I give Orcs Must Die an Old-School Game/10
Orcs Must Die is simple, and that's a good thing. It's rather short compared to modern day games, but that's because of the replay value in getting 5 Skulls [Stars] in every level and using them for upgrades. Also, the writing is great, I love it.
Though when I give this game an¬†Old-School Game/10 I also mean that in the game has aged somewhat. Like, it doesn't have rebinding and subtitles.
Orcs Must Die is like an Old-School Game you'd find on the SNES, it's short, simple fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116113043', 'num_games_owned': 173, 'num_reviews': 174, 'playtime_forever': 851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1648907148}
review:
Orcs Must Die! ist wie sein Nachfolger ein zweischneidiges Schwert.
Zun√§chst mal muss ich sagen, dass mir hier das Waffenhandling deutlich besser gef√§llt als im Nachfolger. Kopfsch√ºsse sind etwas einfacher und das Feedback der einzelnen Waffen l√§sst nicht noch fast eine Sekunde auf sich warten.
Aber alles andere ist leider ebenso schlecht, wenn nicht sogar schlechter als in Teil 2.
Die ersten Level sind Kindergarten. Sie sind zu einfach und dadurch fast schon langweilig. Es kommt nie ein Siegesgef√ºhl auf, weil das alles so geschenkt ist. Die Level im zweiten Akt sind da besser, mehrere Wege f√ºr die Orks und mehr das Gef√ºhl, dass man gerade etwas geschafft hat. Allerdings zieht der Schwierigkeitsgrad von einem Moment auf den n√§chsten so stark an, dass es unverh√§ltnism√§√üig wirkt. Man wird vollgeklatscht mit Ogern, die mehr aushalten als 300 Orks zusammen und die Level sind so designed, dass du am Anfang nichts anderes kannst, als zu verlieren. Nach etlichen Versuchen klappt es dann, aber es ist eher eine Hin und Her Hetzerei als ein spa√üiges Erlebnis.
Nachdem ich mich dann im letzten Level hunderte Male ge√§rgert habe, weil der √úberblick fehlte und weil Gegner viel zu stark sind, habe ich dann doch noch den Nightmare-Mode ausprobiert. Der ist in den ersten Leveln wieder l√§cherlich einfach und zieht ebenso pl√∂tzlich den Regler hoch. Und damit du noch mehr von dieser sch√∂nen Hetzerei hast, bekommst du nicht einmal Vorbereitungszeit, sondern startest INSTANT in die erste Welle, ohne dass du was aufbauen konntest. Das hat mich h√§ufig zur Wei√üglut gebracht, denn so kann man einfach nicht planen und der Anfang von jedem Level wird zur Tortur.
Zus√§tzlich kommt hinzu, dass Gegner mehr Leben haben und man selbst weniger. Au√üerdem teilen sie mehr Schaden aus. Das wei√ü ich aber nicht durch das Spiel - sondern aus dem Wiki. Das Spiel versagt n√§mlich darin, genau diese Daten mitzuteilen.
Wie viel Schaden machen ich und meine Fallen? Upgrades sagen dir, dass du 33% mehr Schaden machst. Aber 33% mehr von "Keine Ahnung" ist immer noch "Keine Ahnung".
Wie viel Leben haben ich und meine Gegner? Gerade bei den gr√∂√üeren Gegnern w√§re es sinnvoll zu wissen, wie man am besten gegen die vorgeht. Das habe ich mir alles selbst zusammengelesen, au√üerhalb des Spieles.
Wie viel Schaden machen meine Gegner? Bzw: Welchen Gegnern sollte ich eher ausweichen und sie aus der Ferne erledigen, statt in den Nahkampf zu gehen?
Die meiste Zeit, w√§hrend ich dieses Spiel gespielt habe, habe ich geflucht, gew√ºtet und geragequittet. Spa√ü hatte ich zwar auch, aber nicht genug. Der einzige Grund, weshalb ich es durchgespielt habe ist, dass ich sowas schlecht auf mir sitzen lassen kann und es beenden muss.
Noch ein Wort zur Story: Die passiert so nebenbei und man kann sich w√§hrend dem Orkgemetzel gar nicht auf die Gespr√§che der Charaktere konzentrieren. Was aber ultra-schade ist, denn die Grundidee klingt so genial. Ich w√ºrde gerne mehr √ºber diese beiden Welten und die magische Verbindung √ºber die Spalte erfahren. Aber es wird mir alles vorenthalten bzw. w√§hrend ich mich konzentrieren muss an den Kopf geworfen.

author: {'steamid': '76561199055204376', 'num_games_owned': 1514, 'num_reviews': 635, 'playtime_forever': 1242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 764, 'last_played': 1646312510}
review:
It really pains me to say this but I can't recommend the game. The first few levels are fun but they are also ridiculously easy and you can't really get a sense of accomplishment. A few levels are challenging and a few are so increadlibly hard that they are no fun, especially when you want to get 5 skulls (no deaths, no enemies got through, make it in time). I can't get 5 skulls in the final level no matter how many times I try/ different strategies, etc, nothing will work. Most levels are doable with the right strategy but not the last one.
I could have looked past that but then the nightmare mode is even more frustrating. I am struggling even in the first act because not only are the enemies much harder to kill, I have less health and less money etc but I also have to fight the hardest enemies (armoured oger, 4 gnolls in one wave,...) you also have NO TIME to prepare for the enemies. 3 seconds is all you get and no breaks in between. The levels that were maybe challenging in normal are just not doable anymore.

In general the game is much harder than the second one and not in a good way. It is also less fun to play alone and you feel overwhelmed quite a lot. If you like the look of the game, get the second one, it's balanced a lot better and way more fun to play.
